description.narrative: Long term environmental sustainability and resilience of food production systems

Output 1.1: Operational multi-stakeholder platforms are supporting INRM at district and regional levels 1.1.1 Number of multi-stakeholder platforms established supporting INRM per district, within which a percentage of women, men, youth, and indigenous people are represented
Output 1.2: Adequate legal instruments enabling INRM, land use planning and enforcement in place
1.2.1 Number of legal instruments, policies, by-laws applied in Karamoja sub-region enabling INRM, land use planning and enforcement
OUTCOME 2: Increased land area under integrated natural resources management (INRM) and SLM practices for a more productive Karamoja landscape Output 2.1: Institutional technical capacities are strengthened to implement INRM/SLM 2.1.1 Number of people trained on INRM, among which a percentage are women
Output 2.2: Increase in the number of community members trained in INRM / SLM techniques 2.2.1. Number of community members trained in INRM and SLM practices, 60% of which are women
Output 2.3: Community groups are benefiting from income-generating activities (IGAs) introduced by the project 2.3.1. Number of people participating in alternative livelihoods schemes addressing SLM/INRM in the broader Karamoja landscape, 60% of which are women
1.3.2. Increase in household incomes measured by household surveys
Output 2.4 Community level small grant projects in the Karamoja region that enhance ecosystem services, sustainable land management, innovate alternative livelihood options, are implemented
2.4.1. Number of Civil Society practicing SLM / INRM issues in Karamoja through the Small Grants Program.
OUTCOME 3. Framework in place for multi-scale assessment, monitoring and integration of resilience in production landscape and monitoring of GEBs

Output 1: Operational multi-stakeholder platforms are supporting INRM at district and regional levels 1.1.1 00 multi-stakeholder platforms established supporting INRM per district, within which a percentage of women, men, youth, and indigenous people are represented
1.2.1 00 legal instruments, policies, by-laws applied in Karamoja sub-region enabling INRM, land use planning and enforcement. OUTCOME 2: Increased land area under integrated natural resources management (INRM) and SLM practices for a more productive Karamoja landscape 2.1.1: 00 people trained on INRM, 30% women Output 2.2: Increase in the number of community members trained in INRM / SLM techniques. 2.2.1. 00 community members trained in INRM and SLM practices, 60% of which are women. Output 2.4. Community level small grant projects in the Karamoja region that enhance ecosystem services, sustainable land management, innovate alternative livelihood options, are implemented.
2.4.1. 20 Civil Society Organizations practicing SLM / INRM issues in Karamoja through the Small Grants Program. OUTCOME 3. Framework in place for multi-scale assessment, monitoring and integration of resilience in production landscape and monitoring of GEBs Output 3.1: Assessment and Monitoring of GEBs from project interventions. 3.1.1 01 baseline survey for selected sites using appropriate assessment methodology and tools conducted.
Output 3.2: Capacity in place to apply appropriate tools and practices for monitoring resilience at multiple scales. 3.2.1 01 capacity building for PMU and project beneficiaries in methods and tools for rigorous Monitoring and evaluation of project indicators and participatory monitoring. Output 3.3. Project is linked to Regional Hub program for knowledge generation, exchange and dissemination. 3.3.1. Participate in 01 regional program activities including study tours, research, knowledge sharing.

1.1.1.No (zero) multi-stakeholder platforms were established. 1.1. 2 no (zero) legal instruments were applied to foster land use planning and enforcements -awareness was created to the masses that attended the World food day that was celebrated in Nabuin, Moroto District.
2.1.1 No (zero) trainings were held for communities on INRM. 2.1.2 IEC materials were developed to create awareness about the project and these were disseminated on the world food day. 2.1.3 Capacities of district land officers and local councils on application of INRM and related guidelines were not built.
2.2.1 No (zero) communities were trained on INRM and SLM practices
2.4.1 No (zero) civil society Organizations practicing SLM/INRM issues in Karamoja through the small grants
3.1.1 capacity building for the PMU on tools for collection of data on GEBs was not done 3.1.2 No participation in regional activities for information sharing were attended.

Support local councils, district planning and land offices in the review or establishment of community-based land use plans

Output 1.1: Operational multi-stakeholder platforms are supporting INRM at district and regional levels 1.1.1. Assessment and strengthened existing sectoral, interest-based and stakeholder-based platforms in Karamoja and needs assessment. Output 1.2: Adequate legal instruments enabling INRM, land use planning and enforcement in place 1.2.1 Facilitate the review / amendment / drafting of by-laws & ordinances to ensure the integration of INRM and diversified production systems Output 2.4 Community level small grant projects in the Karamoja region that enhance ecosystem services, sustainable land management, innovate alternative livelihood options, are implemented 2.4.1 Deliver small grant projects focusing on restoration of ecosystem services, forest cover and biodiversity, water harvesting and conservation, implementation of erosion control techniques, innovative sustainable livelihoods and livelihoods approaches, post-harvest management, business skills development, with attention to gender-based strategies.
Output 3.1: Assessment and Monitoring of GEBs from project interventions. 3.1.1. Select assessment methodology and tools and conduct baseline survey for selected sites Output 3.2: Capacity in place to apply appropriate tools and practices for monitoring resilience at multiple scales 3.2.1. Participation in 01 regional program activities including study tours, research, knowledge sharing

Output 1 1.1.1. An assessment was done and existing platforms in the region were identified. Capacity of stakeholders in the Honey production value chain was built through a training. Information and Education materials including Brochures, T-shirts and project briefs were produced in different languages and distributed during the World Food Day that was cerebrated in Karamoja this year.
Output 2.1 2.1.1. Eight (8) byelaws and four (4) ordinances directly related to INRM were identified but integration of these into DDPs did not start( Review of Land use plans was not started yet but it was initiated through an MoU developed with Busitema University District level technical persons (157 participants (F41:M116)) were trained on land issues, guidelines that govern natural resource management)
Output 3.1 3.1.1.Assessment methodology and tools were developed and baseline survey for selected sites was initiated PMU and Technical persons at district level were trained during the process of data collection which s still on-going. Output 3.2 3.2.1.Capacity to utilize the tools has not yet been developed.
